Posted By: blindthrall (5/6/2012 5:02:30 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Better than he looks, I think, with the proper considerations.  
  
The most important thing to remember about Tibalt is that unlike most other 'walkers, you don't want to be using him every turn. Leave him out, keep him protected with blockers and spot burn, and +1 when it'd be advantageous to do so. Keep him around long enough and you'll get tons of value out of him, especially if you line up his -4 after a [Reforge the Soul](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Reforge the Soul) or such, just don't expect him to do tons of flashy things every turn. His value is a lot more subtle than we're used to Planeswalkers being, especially in red.
posts.html:
Better than he looks, I think, with the proper considerations.

The most important thing to remember about Tibalt is that unlike most other 'walkers, you don't want to be using him every turn. Leave him out, keep him protected with blockers and spot burn, and +1 when it'd be advantageous to do so. Keep him around long enough and you'll get tons of value out of him, especially if you line up his -4 after a Reforge the Soul or such, just don't expect him to do tons of flashy things every turn. His value is a lot more subtle than we're used to Planeswalkers being, especially in red.

Posted By: tahunuva (5/1/2012 9:26:50 PM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
Just some random thoughts after looking at this card:  
  
1. I love it that there is a Planeswalker who actually can beat [Mana Leak](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mana Leak) to the punch, assuming you go first.  
  
2. This card makes me want to take another look at [Slag Fiend](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Slag Fiend) and [Kuldotha Phoenix](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Kuldotha Phoenix), as I always wanted to build a deck around the two.  
  
3. It is pretty obvious that wizards is trying to push red graveyard decks when you consider cards like this and [Faithless Looting](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Faithless Looting).  
  
4. Turn 2: Mountain, then Tibalt, then use his +1.  
 Turn 3: Mountain, then [Volt Charge](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Volt Charge), then use his -4
posts.html:
Just some random thoughts after looking at this card:

1. I love it that there is a Planeswalker who actually can beat Mana Leak to the punch, assuming you go first.

2. This card makes me want to take another look at Slag Fiend and Kuldotha Phoenix, as I always wanted to build a deck around the two.

3. It is pretty obvious that wizards is trying to push red graveyard decks when you consider cards like this and Faithless Looting.

4. Turn 2: Mountain, then Tibalt, then use his +1.
Turn 3: Mountain, then Volt Charge, then use his -4

Posted By: Judgemaster_Rolan (5/9/2012 10:49:44 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I'm really skeptical about Tibalt. His +1 is pretty controversial at the moment and I'm leaning on the side of the naysayers. There are some instances where this can be useful, but I feel like red decks would rather have another burn spell in that slot. If Madness gets brought back as a mechanic or flashback cards become more playable, he'll be a force to reckon with. His -4 is very good against control, but not much else. His -6 is pretty underwhelming for me, but Wizards has been pushing creatures like crazy so maybe it'll be useful more often than not.  
  
Overall, he require very subtle play and I'm not convinced he's worth the effort.  
  
3/5
posts.html:
I'm really skeptical about Tibalt. His +1 is pretty controversial at the moment and I'm leaning on the side of the naysayers. There are some instances where this can be useful, but I feel like red decks would rather have another burn spell in that slot. If Madness gets brought back as a mechanic or flashback cards become more playable, he'll be a force to reckon with. His -4 is very good against control, but not much else. His -6 is pretty underwhelming for me, but Wizards has been pushing creatures like crazy so maybe it'll be useful more often than not.

Overall, he require very subtle play and I'm not convinced he's worth the effort.

3/5

Posted By: blindthrall (5/6/2012 5:02:30 AM)
Rating:

posts.post_content:
I don't think Tibalt will not see much play outside the first few days... Once that "WOW, he's 2 CMC!" factor dies down, he'll just become a joke.   
  
Why? Well, here's two reasons why:  
  
1 - He's all red - Nothing makes a great card slightly less great than restricting the mana you must spend (EG [Phyexian Obliterator](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Phyexian Obliterator), [Leatherback Baloth](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Leatherback Baloth), [Arcanis, the Omnipotent](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Arcanis, the Omnipotent) (to a degree)). This means that you either have to play mono-red, or suffer slightly on turn 3 if you don't have the other colours out.   
  
2 - Randomness - Sure, it's fun to rely on chance... but when you could discard your 'main event' card (like a mythic of some sort), only to draw a land or something, it becomes more of a joke... on you.  
This is also why people would rather play [Faithless Looting](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Faithless Looting) over [Desperate Ravings](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Desperate Ravings). If his ability was more like [Mad Prophet](/Pages/Card/Details.aspx?name=Mad Prophet)'s, then he'd be worth every penny... but now.... [(see all)](javascript:void(0);)

This means that you either have to play mono-red, or suffer slightly on turn 3 if you don't have the other colours out.

2 - Randomness - Sure, it's fun to rely on chance... but when you could discard your 'main event' card (like a mythic of some sort), only to draw a land or something, it becomes more of a joke... on you.
This is also why people would rather play Faithless Looting over Desperate Ravings. If his ability was more like Mad Prophet's, then he'd be worth every penny... but now.... (see all)
